subject: RE: [junit] Re: distinguishing between failures and errors

messageBody:
On 2002-07-02 at 12:51 Daniel Barclay wrote:

>> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
>...
>> >...
>> > (How can a test show that the caller is responsible for not
>> > passing in a null pointer?
>>
>> I do this by *not* testing that I can handle the null
>> pointer. The absence of
>> a test indicates "undefined behavior" and you shouldn't rely
>> on undefined
>> behavior.
>
>How can the absence of a test specify anything reliably? (How does
>the user know that you're trying to say that the behavior is undefined

>and that you didn't just forget to test that case?)

The user should assume, in my opinion, that unspecified behavior is --
well -- unspecified. I would assume it. If I am unsure what your code
does under specific conditions, I have some choices. I can:

* Read your documentation and trust it.
* Ask you directly.
* Look at your tests and find one that covers the condition or
something sufficiently similar.
* Write a Learning Test and discover the answer for myself.

I could read your documentation, but I may not trust it. I would
certainly be able to trsut the outcome of any of the other three, so
I'm not sure whether the first is that solid an option, all other
things being equal.

To answer the direct question: the absence of a test specifies, by
default, that behavior is undefined. Add a test -- no matter who writes
it -- and we can define the behavior unambiguously. I prefer
unambiguous definitions to potentially ambiguous ones by default, so in
the worst case, I'd probably just write the test. I have tried to do
this without just writing the test before and regretted the wasted
time, so I have decided to learn from my experience.

>> > Because tests, being code, can't relate code to external concepts.

>> >
>> > (A specification can say that a function f returns the
mathematical
>> > sum of two given integers subject to the limitations of 32-bit
>> > signed binary arithmetic. How can a test say something like
that?)
>>
>> I would think that the name of the method says it,
>
>Then you completely missed the example I just gave.

I did not: I think "f" is a ridiculous name and would have to question
any author who names a function like the above "f".

>Note the number
>of terms necessary to define the behavior of the function. Would you
>ever name a function with that level of precision or description?

This does not parse. I thought I specified three tests that zero in
quite quickly on the behavior of this method. What was wrong with them?
Is something missing?

>(Don't use that exact example, since 32-bit binary values are already
>defined in Java.)

I don't see how this matters: are you suggesting that we need an
example of a method using parameters that are "not defined" in Java?

>> I, for one, would be very interested to see Sun's servlet API
>> described in a
>> test suite.
>
>I would hate to see _only_ a test suite.

With a gun to my head and asked to choose between Javadoc and a test
suite, I choose the test suite. I assume that the test suite was ample
to provide the developers with the necessary confidence to release
their code; otherwise, I simply wouldn't use the software at all.

>You know, this makes me think of things like Ada and some network
>protocols, which have a detailed specification _and_ a test suite.

Even better.

>Having just the test suite would be a horrible way to learn Ada or a
>protocol enough to implement it, or even just to use it.

Do you have experience to back up this statement? I started learning
Smalltalk using a combination of:

* Well-named classes
* A primer on the syntax
* SUnit

I found it to be quite a good experience, actually. When learning a
programming language, it is more important to try to write tests than
it is to read tests. Writing tests in an unknown language allows me to
explore the language without being bogged down in the details of I/O,
which can create more questions than they answer. Think about all the
nonsense one has to go over to explain "public static void
main(String[] args)" to a novice Java programmer... would it not be
better to just explain how to call methods and assertEquals()?

>(Actually, doesn't Sun have a J2EE test suite?)

No idea. If they do, I'd like to see it.
